node.title: ‘Reopening Night’ Review: The Show Goes On
node.alt: “Reopening Night,” directed by Rudy Valdez, documents last summer’s production of “Merry Wives” at the Delacorte Theater.
node.description: This HBO documentary goes behind the scenes of the Public Theater’s post-shutdown, modern adaptation of “The Merry Wives of Windsor,” featuring an all-Black cast.
node.content: ["Rudy Valdez\u2019s documentary, \u201cReopening Night,\u201d takes viewers behind the scenes of \u201cMerry Wives,\u201d the Public Theater\u2019s first production after the coronavirus pandemic shut down Broadway and other venues until earlier this year.", "The documentary, which is streaming on HBO, shows the difficulties of mounting a show outdoors while contending with the ever-looming threat of coronavirus: A cast member tests positive, the weather leads to cancellations, and the set pieces are constantly at risk of water damage if it rains.", "\u201cMerry Wives,\u201d a modern adaptation of Shakespeare\u2019s \u201cThe Merry Wives of Windsor,\u201d was staged last summer as part of the Public\u2019s Shakespeare in the Park program. The play, which was set in South Harlem, included an all-Black cast.", "So many things can and do go wrong, but this production diary\u2019s most intriguing element is the way it considers the value of art at a time when the country seems to be on fire. Shakespeare feels \u201cfrivolous,\u201d says one of the cast members, in the face of a national health crisis, protests against police brutality and calls for racial justice.", "Interviews with the members of the cast, crew and staff \u2014 like the playwright Jocelyn Bioh (who adapted the play), the Public\u2019s managing director, Jeremy Adams, and the \u201cMerry Wives\u201d director, Saheem Ali \u2014 reveal complex and deeply personal reasons for such devotion to the theater.", "There would seem to be \u201ca chasm between people of color and Shakespeare,\u201d but many of the performers find his work particularly suited to experimentations with language and the expression of diverse lineages. \u201cMerry Wives\u201d is a showcase for the possibilities of theatrical adaptation.", "But there\u2019s nothing fresh about the execution, and Valdez\u2019s inspirational tone can feel overly saccharine. Nevertheless, \u201cReopening Night\u201d should offer a certain kind of satisfaction for those among us who\u2019ve waited for the return of live theater with jittery anticipation."]
